ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: While the title of the course may not seem all that scintillating, the course is incredibly well designed, and Professor Clark does an admirable job of guiding students through a diverse array of readings. We read a lot of good literature and watched some good films as well; I would absolutely recommend this course if you are interested in approaching "the city" in a slightly interdisciplinary context that combines artistic representations in literature and film.

Yes, absolutely, this class is A hidden gem. The readings and films were interesting, the work light and the professor very nice and engaging. For the life of me I cannot fathom why so few people were enrolled in this wonderful little class.

This course had a pretty great reading list, and covered some very interesting topics, though the format of the class and the lectures/discussions sometimes left a bit to be desired. I really enjoyed all the short stories and essays we read, and most of the novels/novellas were good too, though a couple were too long to really have time to cover in depth. I enjoyed the film selection as well, though I think additional films would've helped (one per week wouldn't really be asking too much). The workload is nice - just two medium-length papers (on anything you want to write about), participation, and a presentation on one week's topic - very manageable. I could go either way as far as recommending the course - you wouldn't miss a whole lot just by tackling the readings/films on your own time, but it's also great to have the incentive to read this stuff and think about it academically.
